sequencing just a quick side view of what actually happens in sequencing we
take a very small sample of DNA we bust it up so DNA is three billion a sequence
of three billion different bases we break it up into many small strands and the things in the middle there are molecules strands say of 200 bases long
we make them stand up on a on a very small sheet called a flow cell and then we get them to all replicate so we
create these little clusters and at the end of that process you have these tiny little clusters of set amounts of DNA
and each cluster has identical clone DNA in it we go through a process is
actually an optical process of because that single-stranded DNA we attach bases
and fill in the other side of the DNA strand if you're familiar with DNA is two interlocking complementary strands
and as each of those is added you can see down the bottom there as we got a little flashlight and it's different
colors for different bases and then by doing some image processing on that we
can actually decompose that into the actual sequence of bases that comprise the DNA chain now the numbers actually
aren't all that impressive if you look at you've got three billion bases and each base there can be one of four bases
so that comes out to 750 megabit megabytes of data so it's kind of amazing a human who can be represented
by seven hundred fifty megabytes of data that the human plan if you will but it turns out we all vary by less than point

another kind of a difference or Delta modulation and so you end up actually with only needing to conceptually or at

the reality is actually very different so the instruments as they're going through that image process they generate
